name: Saibal Chatterjee
review: The fallout of socio-economic disparities that pit one class of people against another has rarely been put on the big screen with the kind of savage candour and devastating intensity that Bong brings.

name: Ricardo Gallegos
review: Bong Joon-ho masterfully sets the table, and then delivers a raw, brutal critique to society. A masterpiece and one of 2019 best films. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Allen Almachar
review: Parasite is a stunning achievement. It's a work that is as keenly prescient as it is superbly crafted.

name: Yasser Medina
review: I can say, without fear of being wrong, that this is one of the best movies of the year. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Damond Fudge
review: Parasite is a masterful piece of social satire and dark comedy, a scathing portrait of both the upper and lower classes.

name: John Beifuss
review: In the movie's most vivid set piece, Bong demonstrates that water (to use a euphemism) rolls downhill: A downpour that is picturesque at the level of the mansion becomes a flood by the time it washes into the poor family's vulnerable neighborhood.

name: Anton Bitel
review: under the guise of an engaging, thrilling, rip-roaring piece of entertainment..., Bong has delivered a spectacular deconstruction of the late-capitalist society in which we all must live together - if not all on the same level.

name: Shikhar Verma
review: Settling in for a narrative about a family trying to keep it together by overpowering the capitalistic battle, Bong Joon-ho has constructed a low-key tragic comedy that insists on being more than just that.

name: Sarah Musnicky
review: PARASITE is Bong Joon Ho's masterpiece.

name: Jim Ross
review: It's very rare a film makes a step-change in what is going on and the dynamics of the characters, and makes that work as well it does here.

name: Damon Wise
review: ...director Bong is also working on other levels, not only making all of its characters relatable - the Parks are really quite sweet people, if a little lacking in self-awareness - but telling his story with a healthy dose of uproarious slapstick.

name: David Keyes
review: A picture that audaciously devours the force of convention and transforms it into a feverish undercurrent, driving what can only be described as an engine through the odyssey of mayhem.

name: Casey Chong
review: Kudos go to Bong's sleight-of-hand narrative approach, as he seamlessly defying genres by alternating from drama to comedy to thriller and back again over the course of its 131-minute running time.

name: Betty Jo Tucker
review: 'Parasite' includes some wish-I-never-saw-that scenes. Viewers who are faint of heart should be forewarned, but horror fans might enjoy the carnage.

name: Micheal Compton
review: A film that is genre-defying and free of the restraints of conventional storytelling.

name: Laura Bradley
review: With each passing day, Bong Joon-ho's class-conscious thriller about a family that lives in a sub-basement-and the blissfully naïve rich family they wind up working for-becomes even more prescient.

name: Julia Swift
review: Get ready for thrills and laughter. As the credits roll, all the layers of meaning in every shot, character and object become clear and you can't wait to spread the word. This is what cinema does best -- entertain, provoke, create discussion.

name: Ben Rolph
review: Everything is superbly controlled and nailed to the point at which you begin to question, how is this possible?

name: Tessa Smith
review: Parasite surprised me over and over. I constantly had no idea what was going to happen next. But what did happen, was amazing and extremely well done.

name: Brian Gill
review: A monumental achievement in film and the rare film that goes from "very good" to "historically great" in its final act.

name: Dan Schindel
review: The smartest mainstream film about class made in many years, Bong Joon-ho's Parasite lays bare the lie that hard work can bring anyone closer to their dreams.

name: Paul Farren
review: Never let the audience off the hook, Hitchcock once said. Ho achieves this in spades and with more than one hook.

name: Michael Wood
review: [A] funny, inventive, scary film.

name: Roe McDermott
review: From his opening shots, Bong Joon-Ho establishes the upstairs/downstairs dynamic of his razorsharp, bleakly funny, unmistakably furious skewering of capitalism and class divides.

name: Ard Vijn
review: Bong hoped to give his film a classic sheen by creating a 'b&w' version. He needn't have done this: with or without color, Parasite will certainly be classic enough.

name: Asia Frey
review: It is bracing, audacious, jarring, challenging and exciting, a devastating social satire realized with precision and intelligence in every perfectly constructed frame.

name: Achara Kirk
review: It's a very good story.

name: Jaby Koay
review: The acting's amazing.

name: Tim Robey
review: I think it's a career peak for [Bong Joon-ho].

name: Simran Hans
review: Watching that drama -- the bricks sort of build and then topple -- is so satisfying.

name: Rebecca Liu
review: Thinking very metaphorically may not lead to our salvation, but the consciousness it induces just might.

name: Sheraz Farooqi
review: Parasite provides a potential turning point for international films in America. Bong Joon-Ho's mystery drama will capture the hearts and minds of audiences worldwide

name: Jeremy Jahns
review: The movie itself - message aside - is remarkably entertaining.

name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
review: It conveys very clear messages about classism and discrimination, [all through] an entertaining and visually arresting story. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Paul Whitington
review: It's a splendid film, beautifully acted and realised, which manages to be both entertaining and profound.

name: Deirdre Molumby
review: A breath-taking cinematic accomplishment that will have you talking for days

name: Clarisse Loughrey
review: [Bong Joon-ho]'s work is as playful as it is sincere and revelatory. He'll make you feel at home, and then rip the rug out from under you.

name: Linda Marric
review: This is what a true masterpiece looks like.

name: Sucharita Tyagi
review: What's to be said about this film that hasn't already been said? ... because there is so much to take in, like a Da Vinci painting, the film reveals secrets and hidden meanings until you're left breathless...

name: Cameron Frew
review: Cinema of the highest form. No headline will ever convey the power of Parasite - it's a masterpiece that has to be seen to be believed.

name: Rosalynn Try-Hane
review: What makes Parasite such a good film is that it tells a story first and foremost, so the social commentary whilst ever present isn't so overpowering that you cannot just enjoy the story being told.

name: Tony Macklin
review: The parasites have parasites.

name: Stephen Rebello
review: Ingeniously written and directed, plus faultlessly acted, this is one of the great movie experiences of this or any year.

name: Matthew Bond
review: Despite the occasionally slow pace, an impressively strong finish means you'll enjoy finding out.

name: Juan José Beteta
review: An impeccable script. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Tom Shone
review: Plugging into our universal disquiet about the inequality between the haves and have-nots, Bong has fashioned a darkly enjoyable class-war thriller in which the real monster is global capitalism itself, but there is nothing heady or didactic about it.

name: Ed Whitfield
review: One's left to wonder who's parasitically living off whom? The Kims off the Parks, or the Americans off their anti-communist allies?

name: Nicola Austin
review: Parasite is a completely gripping and utterly entertaining masterpiece in which writer-director Bong Joon Ho has poured all his craft and vision into.

name: Mark Kermode
review: A tragicomic masterclass that will get under your skin and eat away at your cinematic soul.

name: Kevin Wight
review: This serpentine, unclassifiable piece stands as a highlight among the director's already glittering career.

name: Namrata Joshi
review: Far from hiding, the film's beguiling charm stokes the deeply dystopian vision of its maker. In Bong's world, despite tokens like a cell phone or pizza dinners, social mobility doesn't quite exist.

name: Demetrios Matheou
review: [I]ts delivery - mixing social satire, twisty plotting and Hitchcockian tension - a masterclass in serious-minded but accessible mainstream filmmaking.

name: Mark Kermode
review: I think this film is as close to perfect as anything I have seen in the last 10 years. It's just fantastic.

name: Alistair Harkness
review: [A]s a filmmaker [Bong's] less interested in finger-wagging admonishments than he is in taking us to uncomfortable places with outré plot twists that deepen and reframe what we think we know about the characters.

name: Cath Clarke
review: Using industrial-strength social satire, [Bong Joon Ho] strips the veneer off the myth of classlessness, giving an outrageously entertaining instant classic.

name: Jennifer Clark
review: While Parasite has won critical acclaim worldwide, seeming to strike a chord with audiences for its raw class commentary, the movie's message is not clear cut. It's a dark comedy, but by the end you're not sure if the joke is on you after all.

name: Deborah Ross
review: It works on every level which is, perhaps, fitting for a film about levels and whether you are at the top or bottom in life.

name: Ryan Gilbey
review: Parasite works as entertainment and analysis, treat and treatise.

name: Rafer Guzman
review: An imaginative comedy-thriller with darkness at its core.

name: Steven Sheehan
review: The word masterpiece is often too easily used... But you can easily understand why Parasite has been given that label by so many because finding a reason to disagree feels just as redundant.

name: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh
review: Though we largely root for the Kims, Bong doesn't allow anything as simple as rich versus poor, good versus bad. No wonder this movie speaks to global audiences - it's a parable about our capitalist world.

name: Danny Leigh
review: A film that always has two thoughts in its head at once, a spectacular epic and tightly wound chamber piece, chicly sophisticated, brutal as a hammer.

name: Chris Hunneysett
review: extraordinary

name: Richard Bonaduce
review: It takes a while to get there, but it sticks its landing.

name: John Nugent
review: A miracle of a film. It feels like Bong Joon-ho's already extraordinary career has been building to this: a riotous social satire that's as gloriously entertaining as it is deeply sardonic.

name: Manu Yáñez
review: Bong builds the rocambolesque plot of Parasite from a solid architectural skeleton. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Poulomi Das
review: It's a gripping, existential, horrifying study of a nightmarish world - except that it is true.

name: Nick Rogers
review: We see what we want. We want what we see. Woe unto the collateral damage we leave. There may be no more original schemes, but the best movie of 2019 is more fascinated by original sins and the shapes they take in the here and now.

name: Fernando E. Juan Lima
review: Intrigue, violence, gore and humor show us a Korea in which not everything that shines is gold. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Allen Adams
review: Parasite is staggeringly good, a remarkable piece of filmmaking that immerses and unnerves. Bong Joon Ho's direction is that of a maestro, of an auteur unleashed.

name: Neal Pollack
review: A masterful genre chronicle of savage injustice and a master-class in genre filmmaking from Bong Joon-ho, Parasite is a classic must-see for anyone who loves film.

name: Lewis Knight
review: Quite simply put, Parasite is a thrilling masterpiece from Bong Joon-ho, a director at the height of his powers offering a film that is profoundly entertaining, wonderfully realised, and thought-provoking.

name: Rohan Naahar
review: In Parasite, Bong doesn't appear to be expressing empathy for the poor. Nor does he seem to be pointing fingers at the rich. He is, instead, questioning the very nature of mankind; its self-centred ingratitude and its propensity to create divisions.

name: Alexa Dalby
review: It really is a must-see.

name: Ian Sandwell
review: Very few movies in recent years have left you unsure what's going to happen next, but even when you do, it's still a compelling watch. Quite simply, Parasite is a masterpiece.

name: Katie Smith-Wong
review: Stunning and intricate, it is simply brilliant.

name: Robert Roten
review: It plays like a brilliant con job comedy in the first half, before switching to total wacko mode at the end, with knives out and bloody. I liked the first half of this Jekyll and Hyde film a lot. The second half, not so much.

name: Marcelo Stiletano
review: Bong Joon-Ho here constructs a powerful and intense hybrid of genres, themes, and observations that grow and acquire sense as the story, which is full of rich details, unfolds. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Iván Belmont
review: Humiliation is transformed into resentment and fantasy into reality. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Jorge Ignacio Castillo
review: Parasite is true to itself even when it stops being palatable.

name: Matt Brunson
review: As with his previous features such as Snowpiercer and The Host, Bong has created an intense drama laced throughout with scathing commentary.

name: Kent Garrison
review: Bong Joon Ho has delivered one of the most well-assembled and compelling films of all time, which flawlessly navigates humor, despair, satire, and elements of thrilling horror to create an experience I won't soon forget.

name: Rob Gonsalves
review: Parasite flips through about ten different genres and takes the best bits of each; it feels like a relaxing buffet that expresses and sparks a love of cinema.

name: Mina Takla
review: Parasite is a major accomplishment and a must-see film for anyone who loves cinema.

name: Lapacazo Sandoval
review: Bong builds the smallest moments into something monumental.

name: Paddy Kehoe
review: No doubt Asian capitalist interests are well-served in the end, there won't be rioting in the streets on the back of this one. A film is hardly effective satire if it doesn't point up a route to radical change.

name: Kevin A. Ranson
review: ... playful until it becomes diabolical... only then does (writer/director) Bong Joon Ho show exactly the cards he's holding.

name: Jeffrey Lyles
review: The only real question is how high you'll rank it in your top films of 2019 or the 2010s decade list.

name: Jackie K. Cooper
review: Unexpected, quirky, funny, horrific, dramatic - all of these things, but also just a bit tedious in parts. Not your average movie for sure.

name: Don Shanahan
review: Somewhere, the ghost of Alfred Hitchcock is smiling with glee.

name: Michael Ward
review: Parasite deserves to take its rightful place as one of the decade's finest films.

name: Lou Thomas
review: Parasite is one of those beautiful rarities in cinema, a clever art-house title with much to say that is riotously entertaining and easily accessible.

name: Alejandro Alemán
review: We are facing a remarkable degree of narrative skill. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Randall King
review: Things get darker still... But Bong never lets the movie's dramatic tonal shifts derail the narrative momentum...

name: Carlos Bonfil
review: A splendid movie. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Hugo Hernández Valdivia
review: Parasite makes us see a landscape of injustice that we normally don't want to see. It feels uncomfortable, but it offers us plenty of material for reflection. Bravo! [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Arturo Magaña
review: Bong Joon-ho succeeds in showing us that the worst monster of our reality is the system that we have built. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Luis Fernando Galván
review: Bong is crude, direct, ruthless, and at the same time refined. The director doesn't deliver a moralizing discourse. On the contrary, he offers a crescendo where suspense and the grotesque come together. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: James Kendrick
review: an elaborate thriller that at first seems to pit the have's against the have-not's, but is ultimately about how the have not's are forced to turn against each other in the mad clamor for whatever dwindling social and economic crumbs they can find

name: Alonso Díaz de la Vega
review: We are before a remarkable degree of narrative skill. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Sarah Boslaugh
review: a parable about two families in Korea-one rich but dim, one poor but clever-and what happens when the poor household decides to scam the rich.

name: Phil Guie
review: Just when we think we know where the narrative is headed, Bong pulls the rug out from under us via turns that are occasionally dazzling, yet always organic, thanks to meticulous foreshadowing and his knack for slowly building an atmosphere of dread.

name: Fico Cangiano
review: Bong Joon-ho delivers something really special: the best film of 2019. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Rich Juzwiak
review: Parasite was too on the nose too often for me to give it my full heart. However, I loved an ambiguity at its core...

name: Jennie Kermode
review: This is a mature, beautifully crafted piece of work and much cleverer than it initially appears.

name: Alberto Sáez Villarino
review: [A] fantastic film. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Jorge Rivera Rubio
review: The conversation about the gap between social classes is cynical, fun, and exasperating, because Bong doesn't simply talks about rich versus poor, but things that few people dare to talk about. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Dorothy Woodend
review: I haven't seen another film that pinned down the essence of the year, wriggling and squirming, with such eviscerating precision. It's not just a film; it's a vivisection.

name: Paul McGuire Grimes
review: The only thing that you should expect is the unexpected.

name: Sarah Ward
review: This isn't just a killer picture on all of the standard levels, however. Contemplating society's growing class collisions and inequities, Parasite also makes a killer statement.

name: Wilson Kwong
review: Parasite is cinema at its very best, and will continue to be lauded as a timeless masterpiece.

name: Daniel Barnes
review: It's the perfect mix of the director's penchants for tidy symbolism and unhinged tonal shifts, with a strong ensemble cast led by longtime Bong favorite Song Kang-ho.

name: Frantz Jerome
review: Parasite is a well-designed kick down the stairs that you cannot see coming. Rarely does a movie take you on the kind of trip this one does.

name: Leah Greenblatt
review: If the movie is a Rorschach of who you identify as parasite and host, it's a test you're just as likely to fail; a filmgoing experience that refuses to fit into any box, and forces viewers to breathe the dangerous air outside of it too.

name: Gregory Ellwood
review: Obviously, these are not new themes or issues unheard of within the global economy, but it's not often a filmmaker finds a way to portray it in such unique shades of grey.

name: Nathaniel Bell
review: Even if its social message about culture and class (Alfred-Hitchcock-by-way-of-Karl-Marx) is laid on too thick in the end, this Parasite slithers most agreeably.

name: Pete Vonder Haar
review: Parasite is a triumph by a director who still hasn't really made a misstep.

name: Andrew O'Hehir
review: It isn't an easy ride, and as with life in the non-metaphorical world, the destination is uncertain. You'll see strange and wonderful things along the way.

name: Panos Kotzathanasis
review: The entertainment this combination of crime thriller and social drama offers is undeniable.

name: Emma Stefansky
review: It's so easy for otherwise good and normal people to do terrible things, and it's never entirely possible for them to escape their sins.

name: Bruce R. Miller
review: [Parasite] has so much to offer, you'll want to see it more than once.

name: Mel Campbell
review: Impeccable, sustaining shocking plot twists and tonal shifts between suspense, poignant family drama and slapstick farce without ever sacrificing its visual flair and impudent sense of humour.

name: Sean Fennessey
review: This movie is scary and funny and utterly beguiling. If you haven't seen it, you must.

name: Bob Chipman
review: Has other, more interesting, uncomfortable things on it's mind - and the most uncomfortable of all is [when] you start to realize none of these people are as bad as you want them to be.

name: Terry Mesnard
review: Parasite is a mature and complex examination of the cyclical nature of the haves and have-notes. It's probably the best film I've seen this year.

name: Eve Tushnet
review: This is a movie about messages, codes and plans, subterranean communications and misperceptions. Parasite may even be a "message movie," though it has an artistry that term conceals.

name: Malik Adán
review: Parasite ups the ante by presenting the (sometimes literal) moral depths of the dream of class mobility.

name: Loren King
review: Bong drags human greed and its consequences into the light with his lacerating wit, unabashed brutality and heart-wrenching tragedy, turning "Parasite" into an audacious and explosive parable for our times.

name: Eli Glasner
review: a savage and spectacular social satire

name: Amanda Mazzillo
review: Parasite is a well-made, engaging, and memorable film exploring class disparity in Korea. With its darkly comedic tone, Parasite manages to entertain, while crafting a surprising and socially relevant experience.

name: Nick Boyd
review: While the off-beat nature of the narrative surely will not appeal to everyone, those with a desire to be taken on a thrilling ride of many twists and turns will be rewarded with an unpredictable and unsettling sharp class dissection.

name: Justin Brown
review: I was just glued to the screen...amazing.

name: Brandon Collins
review: I tried to predict what was happening, and I was wrong every time. I like that...the acting was a bit different, and it took some time to get up to speed, but I really enjoyed it.

name: Tony Baker
review: The cast is great in this film, the performances are really dope and l you really get into both families.

name: Carey-Ann Pawsey
review: In a demonstration of masterful filmmaking director Bong Joon Ho's (Snowpiercer, The Host) latest film is uncategorizable and that is a great thing.

name: Chris McCoy
review: Parasite is at once a comedy and a Hitchcockian thriller with shades of mid-period Cohen Bros thrown in for good ironic measure. This film is a solid must-see for anyone who values quality filmmaking with something to say.

name: Kathryn Reklis
review: Bong Joon-ho's magnificent genre-bending movie Parasite is a funny, deeply satirical look at class divisions, told through the intersecting lives of three families in Seoul.

name: Isaac Feldberg
review: Parasite is a carnivorous and ferocious feat of filmmaking, bloodsport framed with a formal brilliance and brutally comic verve. It's one of the year's best.

name: Brian Orndorf
review: Bong knows better than to deliver a lecture. Instead, he wants nails chewed to the cuticle and armrests bent, achieving such reactions with magnificent editorial flow.

name: Andrew Wyatt
review: Parasite attests to a filmmaker at the peak of powers, telling precisely the story he wants to tell in a way that showcases his distinctive virtuosity.

name: John Anderson
review: It is a sitcom with teeth and haunting moral echoes, no small amount of vulgarity and a smart streak of comedy.

name: Edwin Arnaudin
review: Bong packs his frames with visual symbolism that speaks to contemporary times and writes characters on both sides of the economic divide that feel relatable and well-rounded.

name: Alan French
review: There's little doubt that Parasite earns the title of masterpiece, and will only grow in the public consciousness for decades to come.

name: Susan Granger
review: Bong Joon-ho's suspenseful, timely thriller that's perhaps one of the best movies of the year.

name: Sarah Knight Adamson
review: The film is sarcastically brilliant, hysterical, clever, and frenzied. The cinematography is glorious! My advise, go in not knowing the details!

name: Tim Brennan
review: There's not a doubt in my mind that Parasite is one of the best films of 2019, if not the best film of the year.

name: Eileen Jones
review: I'm still in considerable pain from watching Parasite, days later. It's that great of a film.

name: Monica Reid
review: With Parasite, Bong Joon-Ho has produced a brilliant social commentary, and what might well be the best film of 2019.

name: Diane Carson
review: As with his earlier works... [director Joon-ho Bong] embeds a biting social critique in a dynamic narrative with unexpected risks and satisfying surprises.

name: Michael Calleri
review: South Korean director Bong Joon-Ho's "Parasite" contains everything that's exciting about his films: a grand fluidity of camera movements and a framing of shots that makes you look into corners just in case something's lurking. B

name: Brad Keefe
review: A twisty and uproarious thriller, "Parasite" packs a ton of entertainment around some sharp and timely social satire.

name: Eric D. Snider
review: A scathing satire-farce-tragedy-horror... You might not like where it goes, but you certainly won't forget it.

name: Jeff Simon
review: Parasite is a great film all right. It is not, I think, to be missed by anyone who seriously cares about movies.

name: David Nusair
review: Filmmaker Bong does a superb job of immediately drawing the viewer into the deliberately-paced proceedings...

name: Louisa Moore
review: One of the most intriguing, intelligent, and disturbing films of the year.

name: Elaine Cho
review: Parasite exudes cultural specificity, with deep cuts to Korean headlines and reality TV shows.

name: Sergi Sánchez
review: It's difficult to find a recent movie that defines in such a visual way, through domestic architecture, the perverse mechanisms of domination of neoliberal capitalism. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Jeff York
review: Bong Joon Ho has not only delivered one of 2019's very best movies, but the symbolism he's woven throughout the picture is some of the finest placed on film in years.

name: Rachel Wagner
review: The writing is fantastic, as well as the acting, production design and score

name: Frank Swietek
review: A trenchant commentary on the economic divide that exists in today's South Korea, one made all the keener by Bong's ability to meld elements of comedy, satire, suspense and horror...one of the year's best films.

name: Karl Delossantos
review: Parasite very much takes place in our world. Perhaps a slightly heightened version of it, but ours nonetheless. Mixing that with his usual dark humor and oddly specific characters, Bong Joon-ho has created an experience like no other.

name: Rick Kisonak
review: That's not "savage commentary." That's condescension. This is by far the filmmaker's most commercially successful work to date...

name: Cate Young
review: Parasite is unique in its treatment of class and solidarity and is a singular cinematic experience.

name: Kiko Martinez
review: A meticulously crafted, satirical thriller that proves to be [Bong Joon] Ho's most thematically rich project to date.

name: Chris Stuckmann
review: Parasite is a beautiful movie, wonderfully acted, impeccably shot.

name: Caillou Pettis
review: Parasite is a wholly riveting experience with an astonishingly gripping story that is rich with complex themes, developed characters, and brilliant direction.

name: Tim Brayton
review: A bit overlong at 132 minutes, but generally so kinetic and vivacious that it never once feels boring.

name: Nate Adams
review: Bong Joon-ho's wild 'Parasite' is 2019's first real masterpiece

name: Matt Ward
review: A contender for the best film of the decade, Parasite is a thrilling, absolute masterpiece from one of the world's greatest auteur directors.

name: Marta Sanz
review: Do not miss this movie, it's a love song to the cinema. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Adam Graham
review: It's a fitting movie for our times, and Joon-ho delivers with uncompromising clarity and vision. See it before the inevitable American remake sands down all its razor sharp edges.

name: John Urbancich
review: Joon-ho makes it all increasingly funny at first, until an out-of-nowhere twist sends both families into a sparkling but serious assortment of genre-mixed rides and wrinkles.

name: Evan Dossey
review: A once-a-decade social satire masterpiece.

name: Annlee Ellingson
review: A thriller of the domestic variety -- with a playful sense of humor, startling twists and turns, and keen examination of class.

name: Don R. Lewis
review: Parasite is a brilliant film and one of the best films of the year, and not just best foreign films. It's heartfelt and funny. Mean spirited and sad.

name: Paula Farmer
review: Just when you thought a Bong Joon-ho movie couldn't get more weird or wonderful, he delivers a masterpiece.

name: Ryan Syrek
review: The bassline of modern art is thumping and pulsating with a fury about inequality. Often, that sound gets understandably but simplistically distilled into "rich bad, poor good" messaging. Parasite absolutely defies a quick synthesizing of its message.

name: Rob Thomas
review: Which family is the real parasite, feeding off the other, is a provocative question that lingers long after the movie's ended and our heart rates have returned to normal.

name: Sandy Schaefer
review: Funny, disturbing, and heartbreaking all at once, Parasite finds Joon-ho in top form as a storyteller, delivering a film like no other this year.

name: Sean P. Means
review: "Parasite" is entertaining and shocking, a thought=provoking examination of class differences that shifts effortlessly from comedy to social commentary to something approaching horror.

name: Roxana Hadadi
review: Bong Joon Ho's Cannes winner Parasite is a fantastically dark, horrendously bleak portrait of classist indoctrination.

name: Peter Canavese
review: Wild-ride entertainment that's by turns funny, squirmy, horrifying, and poignant, all in service of a zeitgeist-y story of working-class frustration...boiling over in ways the blithely wealthy can no longer ignore.

name: Hope Madden
review: Every time you think you've pinned this film down-who's doing what to whom, who is or is not a parasite-you learn it was an impeccably executed sleight of hand.

name: Kristian M. Lin
review: Seals a serious case for Bong Joon-ho as one of the great filmmakers of all time.

name: Tom Santilli
review: The latest film from Bong Joon Ho is funny, thrilling and poignant, and is a must-see for anyone looking to fill out their Best of 2019 scorecards.

name: Guillem Martinez Oya
review: A movie about how the capital invades our lifes and our private spaces. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Jared Mobarak
review: A wild ride [where] privilege and exploitation prove to be traits that are at once synonymous and adversarial depending on who wields which and upon whom.

name: Dan Murrell
review: Parasite is a must-watch in order to get a full picture of the world cinema scene in 2019.

name: Eleanor Ringel Cater
review: Perhaps the greatest compliment one can pay "Parasite" is you're never sure what's going to happen next.

name: Joe Friar
review: The con is on in this masterful tale from South Korean director Bong Joon-ho. Filled with twists and turns executed to a tee by the superb cast. Bong and co-writer Han Jin-won easily deliver the best original screenplay of the year. Flawless.

name: Zhuo-Ning Su
review: It is breathtaking to observe how Bong juggles the many different tones and themes in one, masterful piece of screenwriting.

name: Víctor López G.
review: A single piece that touches deep into the heart, exciting, marveling, and shivering as only masterpieces can do. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Ignacio Navarro
review: Bong designs a structure where the targeted layers are not so much the final objective... but the wrapping of a story of intrigue where the details of the sequences and the rhythm with which they happen are more important. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Max Weiss
review: Parasite is stuffed with everything-gorgeous architecture, beautiful people, shocking violence, ingenious twists, wicked humor, and clear-eyed social commentary.

name: Christopher Llewellyn Reed
review: We are all trapped by the system, though some of us are trapped in gilded cages, whiles others live among the rats.

name: Roger Moore
review: An amusing and scathing social satire that will resonate from Seoul to Syracuse, Helsinki to Hong Kong, one of the great films of 2019.

name: Martin Tsai
review: With "Parasite," Bong Joon-ho gives the "Upstairs, Downstairs" premise a long-overdue update.

name: Michelle Kisner
review: Timely in its class divide critique, Parasite balances dark satire with heartwarming family dynamics.

name: Jonathan W. Hickman
review: "Parasite" is a timely commentary about our era of the classist "gig" economy, in which the transactional overcomes decency and humanity.

name: Lisa Trifone
review: Parasite boasts one of the most pitch-perfect ensembles of recent memory.

name: Andrew J. Salazar
review: The fact that it manages to blend dark comedy and suspense while also being accompanied by unforgettable crisp visuals makes it stand out from most films released within years.

name: Julie Crawford
review: A standing ovation to cinematographer Kyung-pyo Hong, who also lensed the visually impressive Snowpiercer, for setting the perfect tone.

name: David Poland
review: Bong Joon Ho shifts style from one genre to the next throughout the film, but always finds the universal humanity that brings the audience in for more than just laughs and thrills.

name: Martin Thomas
review: It's just so rare to get a movie that actually surprises you these days...

name: Korey Coleman
review: There was so much going on, and all of it came together for one sensible thing...this is the kind of stuff Hollywood makes because they can't make it for themselves.

name: Sadaf Ahsan
review: A masterful commentary on class, Parasite issues a new guideline for contemporary horror.

name: Jaime Fa de Lucas
review: There's no doubt that the idea is interesting and brings about ingenious and really funny scenes. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Adam Kempenaar
review: [The Park's] garage door is the curtain, the grand window looking out from the living room onto the yard is the proscenium, and everything that occurs within its reflection is this symbiotic tragicomedy...

name: Robert Horton
review: You don't want to know too much about it in advance. Parasite unfolds in such a surprising way that watching it work on an audience - through levels of delight, shock and disbelief - is part of the fun.

name: Eric Eisenberg
review: Taking on the disturbingly universal issue of class disparity, the filmmaker has crafted not just a brilliantly sharp and cutting satire, but also what unfurls as a shocking and dramatic thriller with more than a few surprises up its sleeve.

name: Chase Whale
review: Bong Joon-Ho's Lunatic Must-See New Film is His Best and Most Bonkers

name: Jasmyne Keimig
review: The resulting film offers an at turns hilarious and deeply unsettling look at class and survival, its essence echoed in the environments the characters inhabit.

name: Prairie Miller
review: A condescending, pessimistic portrayal of human nature, bereft of class consciousness or ideology...

name: Bill Goodykoontz
review: It's a nearly perfect film, from Bong's masterful use of framing and visual language and control of a wildly shifting tone to the performances (all terrific) to the commentary on class division.

name: Richard Whittaker
review: The entire cast is prepared to make the family unlikable at some level, but this should be a starmaking turn for Park So-dam. Her performance as Ki-jeong and her alter ego, Jessica the art student from Chicago, is raw, caustic genius.

name: Rubin Safaya
review: The cleverness of PARASITE unfolds in slight deviations from what we expect... Mistakes, misperceptions, and misunderstandings accumulate, like heavy rains at the bottom of a long staircase-a drip, a drizzle, a torrent, a deluge.

name: Preston Barta
review: A crazy game of poker. It'll keep you on your toes and will have you hunkering down like a moth to a flame.

name: Nathanael Hood
review: It's a film specifically about false surfaces (both figurative and literal), confidence games, and lies.

name: Grace Randolph
review: Like Joker, Parasite brilliantly explores the haves vs the have nots and how it's becoming an explosive situation. A masterful piece of filmmaking by Bong Joon Ho.

name: Quim Casas
review: Fun and unsettling. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Chris Sawin
review: Parasite is deliciously mischievous and a masterwork of pure and utter deceit with a mesmerizing conclusion that leaves you breathless and reflective.

name: Federico Furzan
review: One of the year's best films. Parasite is a fascinating commentary on society's worst features. [Full review in Spanish].

name: Ken Eisner
review: Parasite radically shifts tones over its wildly entertaining two-hour-plus running time.

name: Cary Darling
review: "Parasite" may be the work that makes (Bong Joon-ho) more of a household name. Many of the best elements from his previous films are on display here, and if there's one film that should serve as an introduction to his style, it's this one.

name: Sean Burns
review: Bong Joon Ho makes genre movies about ideas. His films turn ideology into action, and every shot in 'Parasite' is some sort of argument.

name: Kelly Vance
review: Parasite is an appropriately enigmatic title for a satire that cuts both ways.

name: Linda and Al Lerner
review: Beautiful! Brutal! and Brilliant! This Korean comedy thriller is more like two films in one. Director Bong Joon-Ho (Snowpiercer) has carefully thought out this clever take on the haves and have-nots that we'll call US Plus!

name: Josh Larsen
review: ...like Shoplifters' ugly twin brother, who's kept hidden in the basement.

name: Reuben Baron
review: It gives you a lot to think about, with no clear heroes and extreme moral ambiguity.

name: Matt Oakes
review: [Joon-ho]'s a master of his craft, accounting for the most minute of details while making it look like almost no work at all. His films exert a cool casualness despite their often complicated webs of plots and chameleon-esque tone.

name: Ray Pride
review: Economic disparity may be the greatest subject of the twenty-first century for intimate horror.

name: Jazz Tangcay
review: Joon-ho is an excellent filmmaker and this might just be his piece-de-resistance.

name: Christy Lemire
review: This is the best movie of the year... A tonal marvel.

name: Wade Major
review: An absolutely extraordinary achievement on every conceivable level, even though I think it's a bit of a cheat.

name: Stephen Silver
review: It's an ingenious satire of class that goes to some shockingly dark places. But it's also so, SO funny, finding humor in all sorts of places that the movies rarely do

name: Moira MacDonald
review: You'll watch knowing you're in the hands of a master filmmaker...

name: Clint Worthington
review: It's pure-strain Bong all the way through, surprising and unsubtle in all his appealing glory.

name: Chris Feil
review: Surprising in its observations and developments, the film is has all the makings of one destined for rewatch and deeper examination in perpetuity - a film with the power to continue to reveal things about how we interact and how we survive.

name: Michael Phillips
review: "Parasite" expresses consequential ideas that matter to the filmmaker about the way we live today, and the prejudice and malice we create for ourselves and others.

name: Marianna Neal
review: Let's just get this out of the way: Parasite is the best film of 2019.

name: Ben Sachs
review: Throughout, the director's camerawork and mise en scene are impressively subtle, carefully parsing out information about characters and setting to force viewers to stay alert to the tiniest details.

name: Richard Roeper
review: One of the best movies of 2019, Bong Joon Ho's latest is a film of dramatic power, innovative comedy, romantic poetry and melancholy beauty.

name: Luke Parker
review: One of the year's best, Bong Joon Ho's Parasite is an absurdly masterful dissection of division and greed, and a thunderously assorted filmgoing experience.

name: Anne Brodie
review: Scathingly brilliant, satirical and exquisitely frenzied.

name: Tom Meek
review: By returning to familiar themes and family values, Bong has again latched on to the collective mindset with a touch and a tease of the outré.

name: Ty Burr
review: "Parasite" isn't really a monster movie. Yet on at least one of its nearly infinite levels it is - and the monsters are us.

name: Stuart Klawans
review: Having dramatized the struggle of rich versus poor in wildly lurid terms, he brings the conflict to its dreadful conclusion with the simplest, smallest, most everyday gesture possible.

name: Pat Padua
review: Like a blood-sucking creature that can't let go, the movie is patient and relentless, but unlike its namesake, this "Parasite" is hilarious, gory and, in the end, moving.

name: Mark Dujsik
review: The hilarious, thrilling, and thought-provoking Parasite is a master class of tone control.

name: Alan Zilberman
review: All of its elements-the natural performances, dense plotting, and staggering political implications-coalesce into an undeniably provocative whole.

name: Pat Mullen
review: Few films tap into the cultural zeitgeist as brilliantly and originally as Parasite does.

name: Kyle Turner
review: As we watch both families act in different, but intersecting, pieces of social/anthropological theatre, Bong [Joon-ho] cuts through their mutual hunger, and what ultimately and tragically separates them, with a jaundiced eye and an acidic sense of humor.

name: Peter Sobczynski
review: A one-of-a-kind combination of keenly felt drama and sly social satire that is already a master class in contemporary filmmaking before it shifts narrative gears in ways that need to see to be believed.

name: Jana Monji
review: Expect some blood and a surprisingly poignant ending.

name: Oliver Jones
review: Bong... harnesses the precise anxieties everyone of us is currently sharing-top of that list, the growing income gap and the crumbling planet-and uses them to make every scene in this blackhearted comic thriller crackle with energy and purpose.

name: Mick LaSalle
review: Bong Joon-ho's latest masterpiece and the best film I've seen so far this year...

name: Jim Slotek
review: Gloriously amoral tale of an unscrupulous poor family that connives its way into the mansion of a rich, gullible clan is very funny and very dark. Sure-handed and sly, with a moral compass that wavers as the tables turn

name: Joshua Brunsting
review: Bong takes this battle between classes and one family's attempt to take that much craved next step up the economic ladder, and twists it into a fun house thrill ride.

name: Hau Chu
review: Much like the Kims, a viewer can get lulled into luxuriating in the superficial details of the film. But it's what's lurking below the surface that will stay with you long after the movie is over.

name: Ela Bittencourt
review: Bong harnesses the torment that capitalist greed, deregulation, and gaping inequality have unleashed across the world, making Parasite's dystopian vision ring universally true.

name: Manzanares de la Rosa
review: Parasite is the most powerful, most important, most essential film of 2019, a perfect distillation of style and substance, an ideal conclusion for such an amazing decade for Asian cinema.

name: Rich Cline
review: Bong [Joon-ho] plays merrily with the narrative, spinning it in ways that add clever observations on the themes while deepening characters and keeping the audience both amused and unnerved.

name: Alci Rengifo
review: "Parasite" combines dark humor, social commentary and domestic thriller elements to explore the vicious class divisions in South Korea. Like few recent films it not only captures social relations in its country of origin, but anywhere in the world.

name: Nestor Bentancor
review: Bong Joon Ho dazzles your senses and infects your mind with a delicious concoction of artful entertainment that delivers a poignant cinematic experience. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Kent Turner
review: An unmistakable crowd pleaser ... featuring a linear steel trap of a script.

name: Avi Offer
review: A triumph of directing, writing, cinematography and acting. It's destined to become an all-time classic that will be discussed and analyzed for many years to come. Believe the hype.

name: Rachel Syme
review: What starts out as a fantasy becomes a family's struggle with their place in a global framework designed to keep them down. They realize that getting out of the basement will require more than a few agile maneuvers.

name: Scott Nye
review: Bong Joon-ho's latest film is virtually everything one could desire in a contemporary film.

name: EJ Moreno
review: There's not many movies this year as sleek and polished as Parasite. An absolute delight to watch with Bong Joon Ho proving himself to be a masterful director again.

name: Alan Ng
review: Parasite is a brilliant film and for a thriller, it's absolutely unpredictable...

name: Matthew Lucas
review: Bong masterfully blends these divergent genre elements into one wildly original whole, crafting an incisive indictment of income inequality and the wide gulf between the classes that is as bitterly funny as it is achingly sad.

name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
review: South Korean filmmaker Bong Joon-ho already has an impeccable track record, but he's stepped up his game with this brilliant, powerfully revealing social satire.

name: Kurt Loder
review: A very wild ride, and maybe Bong's best...

name: Terence Johnson
review: Bong Joon-ho has crafted one of the funniest comedies, most bristling class takedowns, creepiest thrillers, and contemplative films of the year.

name: Armond White
review: Bong is an unfunny extremist. In Parasite, he annihilates the concept of the nuclear family by setting a brood of lower-class con artists against an upper-class family unit.

name: Danielle Solzman
review: Parasite may just be the most entertaining genre-bender of the year but more than this, the film brings a fascinating approach to class.

name: David Edelstein
review: What keeps you rapt in Parasite is the visual wit - every shot distills the movie's themes - and the richness of the characters and performances...

name: Anthony Lane
review: Bong, in short, is a merchant of stealth.

name: Leonard Maltin
review: This is the best movie I've seen this year. What begins as a clever social satire about the haves and have-nots in our world morphs into an ingenious (and violent) thriller with endless story twists.

name: Rob Dean
review: There may not be such a thing as a perfect film, but Parasite comes incredibly close.

name: Anne Cohen
review: It's exhilarating, unexpected and, frankly, wild.

name: Joe Morgenstern
review: Imagine a high-wire act where the acrobat suddenly leaps to a higher wire, then to another that's higher still. It's the best way I can think of to describe the giddy thrill of watching Parasite, a masterpiece of serial surprises.

name: Thelma Adams
review: Nimble, funny, complex and heartbreaking, Parasite is a stinging indictment of economic inequality.

name: Mark Kennedy
review: Bong's trademark slapstick is still here but the rough edges of his often too-loud lessons are shaved down nicely and his actors step forward

name: Morgan Rojas
review: An arthouse masterpiece, a strong contender for the best film of 2019.

name: Dave Calhoun
review: This is a dazzling work, gripping from beginning to end, full of big bangs and small wonders.

name: Jeva Lange
review: In terms of sheer enjoyment alone, Parasite delivers. The movie is as darkly funny as its director, and even with a runtime just on the far side of two hours, it never loses its momentum.

name: Vincent Mancini
review: A light farce that gradually transforms into an urgent class parable, getting exponentially more compelling moment by moment. Possibly Bong's best, and certainly one of the best of the year.

name: David Sims
review: All the viewer knows is that Bong is telling a story about humans, which means it can be a perfect comedy until it becomes a tragedy.

name: Rendy Jones
review: As I left the theater, the first words that were uttered under my breath was, "Oh, so this is what Cinema feels like?"

name: Manohla Dargis
review: Bong has some ideas in "Parasite," but the movie's greatness isn't a matter of his apparent ethics or ethos... but of how he delivers truths, often perversely and without an iota of self-serving cant.

name: Jeanne Kaplan
review: This is a uniquely entertaining movie --- one that you can't stop thinking about long after leaving the theater.

name: David Kaplan
review: The ever-suspenseful PARASITE keeps us guessing throughout. ..one of 2019's best-conceived movies.

name: Stephanie Zacharek
review: It tells a story you could probably follow without subtitles, or any dialogue at all: the faces of these actors show with piercing clarity how it feels to be outsiders in a world of wealth and privilege.

name: Joey Magidson
review: Cinematic perfection doesn't come around often. When it does, it's essential to take notice. "Parasite," from top to bottom, is a perfect film.

name: John Nguyen
review: [Parasite] is a crazy, intense, twisted, and dark movie.

name: Katie Walsh
review: "Parasite" is Bong's most sophisticated film to date, expertly plotted with breathtaking reveals, and shot with a smooth, slippery sheen, each frame and camera movement communicating a subconscious plot twist or theme.

name: Peter Travers
review: Let's just say it: the South Korean auteur Bong Joon Ho is some kind of genius and he tops himself with 'Parasite'-it's explosive filmmaking on every level and one of the cinema high points of 2019 . You won't know what hit you.

name: Harvey S. Karten
review: Class warfare among two South Korean families is treated with both comedy and horror in Bong's latest picture.

name: Pete Hammond
review: Bong Joon Ho's Cannes Film Festival winner is a flat out masterpiece.

name: Carla Renata
review: Brilliantly crafted film delving full on into social class, racism within the race with a delicious twist in the final act make Parasite a must-see!

name: Fausto Ponce
review: Parasite is loaded with good performances and memorable characters that go from anecdotal to social radiography. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Brian Truitt
review: "Parasite" attaches to you and doesn't let go.

name: Aaron Neuwirth
review: Parasite is a real gem

name: Katie Rife
review: If anything, Parasite is a condemnation of choosing to ignore the inconvenient suffering of your fellow human beings, presented in a seres of accomplished visual metaphors that'll make you rethink all sorts of ordinary household objects.

name: Jason Escamilla
review: Best Movie of 2019; Parasite has a unique creative story, characters that feel real, and an underlying message about high and low classes, conveyed thrillingly.

name: Kevin L. Lee
review: How Bong gets me to gasp, shriek, and laugh within the span of seconds is beyond me. It's a film that you would want to rewatch the second it's over.

name: Jenny Nulf
review: Bong Joon-ho, who has consistently played with what the class system means in a modern day South Korea, has finally reached his pinnacle with his latest film, Parasite.

name: Andrew Chan
review: At the core of this film is an us-vs-them solidarity that makes even its most contrived narrative payoffs reverberate with emotional authenticity.

name: Nick Johnston
review: Parasite is, in fact, a stunning work from one of the cinema's most reliable masters, and it's a film best seen with virgin eyes and ears, knowing as little as possible about its plot, themes or characters.

name: Kyle Smith
review: Far from being melodramatically schematic, it leaves some ambiguity around the edges, raising questions it doesn't necessarily claim to be able to answer.

name: Lauren Humphries-Brooks
review: By turns hilarious, harrowing, and horrifying, Parasite may well be Bong Joon-ho's best film since Memories of Murder.

name: Rafael Motamayor
review: A tragedy of epic proportions that should scheme, con, and scam its way into many "best of" lists by the end of the year.

name: David Crow
review: This is a darkly amusing masterwork about the never-ending tale of two cities. All in one.

name: Edward Douglas
review: Another fantastically outrageous and weird film ... that continues to show the glory of [Korean] cinema and Director Bong as its master.

name: Alan Cerny
review: Bong Joon-ho's Parasite is a masterpiece, and essential viewing for our times.

name: Eric Webb
review: [A] stylish, exquisite knife to the heart of capitalism's cruelties.

name: Diana Cheng
review: What Bong presents with "Parasite" is a scenario provoking the imaginary. The bottom line could well be just the wild wide of pure entertainment.

name: Dennis Schwartz
review: It's another of Bong's brilliant but hard to label movies.

name: Jonay Armas
review: The work of a... true filmmaker. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Sarah Marrs
review: Parasite is one of the best films you'll see this year, and certainly the most insane.

name: Tom Beasley
review: Parasite's horror lingers in the memory, for sure, but it's the intricately crafted and universal social commentary that truly resonates in our modern times.

name: Kristy Puchko
review: Bong Joon-ho's pitch-black comedy Parasite might his masterpiece.

name: Andrea Thompson
review: Parasite conjures up images of a creature which takes from a victimized host without a thought of giving or the consequences thereof, but as Joon-ho Bong's latest bit of brilliance unfolds, it's unclear just whom is feeding on whom.

name: Oliver Whitney
review: An exhilarating rollercoaster ride that keeps you guessing at every sharp turn, and by the end, leaves you a bit paralyzed by its magnificence.

name: Rene Sanchez
review: A masterpiece in storytelling. Parasite is a dark, twisted and unexpected fable about social injustice. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Alissa Wilkinson
review: While it's hugely entertaining, Parasite is also thought-provoking. By the time the catharsis arrives, you think you're at the end of the film, but a coda adds a new wrinkle to the whole thing.

name: Shubhra Gupta
review: Parasite is many things rolled into one: a sharply observed satire, black comedy, thriller, tragedy.

name: Emmanuel Báez
review: One of those cases where it's easy to use the qualifier "masterpiece". [Full review in Spanish]

name: Adriana Gomez-Weston
review: What Parasite does best is highlight the symbiotic relationship between the rich and the poor. Joon-ho has constantly shown the contrast between the social classes in his work, but Parasite takes the commentary a step further.

name: Sr. Rose Pacatte
review: Parasite... is a clever, dark comedy and social commentary about the invisible working poor who will do anything to survive.

name: Peter Howell
review: Satire morphs into a savage underclass morality lesson that recalls the home invasion tales of Michael Haneke and Jordan Peele.

name: Orlando Maldonado
review: There's no way to predict Parasite, one of those few movies that reinvent themselves at every corner. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Andrew Kendall
review: Parasite inveigles its way into our consciousness. We laugh, at first, at its skewing of reality and the sheer temerity of its main characters. But laughter soon gives way to fright and then to despair.

name: Walter Chaw
review: Parasite goes from Shoplifters to Get Out to Sorry to Bother You in a breakneck way so unsettling you don't notice it happening.

name: Clayton Davis
review: Joon-ho's assured direction, partnered with his passionate and mesmerizing ensemble, "Parasite" emerges as one of the year's most vital and entertaining pieces of filmmaking, perhaps one of the most lively to bookend the decade.

name: Chris Tilly
review: Joon-ho's film straddles multiple genres, with comedy rubbing shoulders alongside drama, thriller, and eventually horror to tell a story that's as entertaining as it is socially incendiary.

name: Norman Wilner
review: It's a hell of a ride - and one of the year's best films.

name: James Clay
review: All and all, this is a film with a razor-sharp edge. It's angry, it's joyous, and - to keep it simple - it's a ton of fun.

name: Dustin Chase
review: Parasite likely works better as a discovery film or severely managed expectations rather than something that's guaranteed to blow audiences away.

name: Chris Bumbray
review: Delicious social satire from a master of the genre.

name: Brian Tallerico
review: Parasite is unquestionably one of the best films of the year.

name: Sarah Kurchak
review: There are at least three perfectly good films squeezed into Parasite's 131 minutes. The way Bong Joon-ho weaves them together, without ever slipping into self-indulgence or excess, is nothing short of masterful.

name: Adam Nayman
review: The speed and ferocity with which things fall apart-and with which Parasite mutates from a sly upstairs-downstairs satire into something more literally and tonally multileveled-is something to behold.

name: Alexandra Heller-Nicholas
review: The success of Parasite is not merely marked by great filmmaking and an intriguing storyline, but deep within its foundations lies an overwhelming understanding on Bong's part of how bigotry operates at an almost molecular level.

name: Courtney Small
review: Effortlessly mixing genres, Parasite is a brilliant work that emphasizes that the stairway to financial freedom is rarely accessible to those who need it the most.

name: Andrew Parker
review: A brilliant, biting, chilling, and darkly hilarious bit of social commentary from Korean master filmmaker Bong Joon-ho that's as entertaining as it is unsettling.

name: Amy Taubin
review: A scathing social satire that fuses raucous comedy with deep despair...

name: Kate Rodger
review: A dark, deeply funny, searingly relevant tale which will remain embedded in my subconscious for my lifetime.

name: Filipe Freitas
review: Parasite offers a lot of wicked pleasures, providing you with a delightfully insane cinematic experience. This is pretty strong filmmaking admittedly and one of the best films of the year in its genre.

name: Oggs Cruz
review: The journey from the first scene to the end is perhaps the most intricate, most scathing, and surprisingly most accessible portrayal of class struggle put into film.

name: Hannah Brown
review: I certainly won't give away any spoilers here, but suffice it to say that you won't guess any of the secrets, and once the story goes down the rabbit hole, it stays very dark till the end.

name: Matthew Toomey
review: Parasite is weird, funny and unforgettable.

name: Wenlei Ma
review: Bong uses everything in his bag of cinematic tricks to craft a dazzling and devastating movie that is part modern-day parable and part family drama. Parasite will variously shock you, make you laugh (guiltily) and make you think.

name: Adam Cook
review: Twists and turns aside, this surprise comes more from Parasite's very make-up: the formal strategies, tonal malleability, and sheer density of the film's intricate construction.

name: Jonathan Barkan
review: Parasite is Bong Joon-ho at his very best. A masterpiece of storytelling and a captivating dissection of class struggles, it is cinema at its finest.

name: Harris Dang
review: Parasite is director Bong in top form; a sadistically funny and dramatically sound cinematic experience that is sure to shock, provoke and linger due to its wonderful performances, audacious storytelling, pitch-black humour and incisive social critique.

name: Damien Straker
review: It is surprising, humorous, completely disturbing, and a thoroughly entertaining addition to this golden age of Asian cinema.

name: John McDonald
review: While Ki-taek's family toast their good fortune, catastrophe lies just around the corner. For the Parks, the fairy-tale of their lives proves too good to be true.

name: Steve Newall
review: Bong has crafted a modern classic... a gripping, frequently funny and often nerve-wracking film...

name: David Stratton
review: Parasite is a subversive delight, and despite its hefty 2 1/4-hour running time is never dull because Bong keeps shifting the goalposts...

name: Leigh Paatsch
review: Devotees of world cinema should make tracks for this right away.

name: Andiee Paviour
review: Out of work like the rest of his hard-up South Korean family, Ki-woo has his world seriously rocked when he scams a job with the loaded Park family.

name: John Lui
review: Social satires rarely come as funny, unpredictable or as generous to its characters as this.

name: Luke Goodsell
review: It's a rollickingly, grim dispatch from a society chowing down on its own entrails, where the underclass are clawing at each other, the rich get twisted up by their own malaise, and everyone's losing their goddamn minds.

name: Joanne Soh
review: Funny, real, gritty and well-supported by a solid cast, the Palme d'Or winner at this year's Cannes Film Festival is a breath of fresh air after the onslaught of Hollywood blockbusters.

name: Vicky Roach
review: A ripping good yarn.

name: Tom Augustine
review: Parasite benefits from crisp, rich cinematography, a deep back-bench of brilliant performers, and a script of clockwork-like precision.

name: Jake Wilson
review: The inspired Parasite can't precisely be labelled a comedy, a thriller, nor a socially conscious drama about the class divide in South Korea, although it contains elements of all three.

name: Graeme Tuckett
review: Parasite is a masterclass in writing and narrative control.

name: CJ Johnson
review: Extremely well crafted and scripted ... Fun, propulsive, ingenious and quite loveable.

name: Simon Miraudo
review: It's a weird but maybe era-appropriate coincidence that the two best films of the year so far-Us and now Parasite-are searing black comedies about class, featuring two rival families whose differences in wealth are largely the result of chance.

name: Jennifer Bisset
review: Coming away from this film will leave you with empathy for those less privileged, and yet the film toys with the idea that even if you do fake your way to the top, you still may ultimately end up back in the basement.

name: William Schwartz
review: Survivalism ain't pretty, but then that's why all the characters in Parasite rich and poor alike have to dress it up as something more noble.

name: Doug Jamieson
review: A masterful portrait of inequality and imbalance, 'Parasite' latches on and never once lets go.

name: Andrew Blackie
review: ...the work of a director intoxicatingly in his element.

name: Lisa Nesselson
review: This dark, dark comedy straddles several genres and is very satisfying.

name: Stephen Garrett
review: The hilariously inventive story has so many unexpected moments of out-there mayhem that it's hard to keep count. And the ways in which Bong turns the screws on the clan of grifters is absolutely riveting.

name: Jo-Anne Titmarsh
review: A riveting and hilarious look at the serious subject of class inequality. Immensely fun and beautifully made.

name: Dennis Lim
review: Parasite puts a wickedly literal spin on the notion that there is always someone lower on the socioeconomic ladder.
